text: The N and the E are not working. So it reads the PR IC mo ROOMS TO RENT BY DAY, WEEK, MONTH. KITCHENETTES. The Prin Motel has passed its prime. A few beat up cars are parked outside rooms. We CRANE DOWN to ROOM SEVEN. Curtains clos but someone is holding it open a crack, looking out. We P in CLOSE TO THE WINDOW and the EYE looking over the parki lot. Then the curtain closes.

Peeling flowered wallpaper, ultra-cheap furniture. The ma moving away from the window is RODRIGUEZ. He is slender,  sports a thin mustache, hair slicked straight back. He's his late thirties. Slightly nervous. Another man sits on the couch, looking at a magazine. He forty, solidly built. His name is FRANK DIVINCI.
Says here they got slips in Honolulu.  325 a month. Utilities included.  That's not bad.
Rodriguez sits down.
But I gotta get at least a forty  footer. It'll handle rough water  better and I'll need the room if I'm  gonna live on it.
Rodriguez stands up, moves back to the window. Divinci lo up.
I don't know how you do it.
What?
How you can think about Hawaii now?
My heart's in Hawaii.
You never been there. How can your  heart be there.
You're tellin' me there's no place  you'd rather be other than here?
No, I'm saying I just don't know how  you can think about Hawaii right  now.
If I was in Hawaii right now, I  wouldn't be thinking about here. See  the difference?
No.
Look, I'm not in Hawaii, I'm here.  But I don't want to be here, I want  to be in Hawaii. I can't be in Hawaii,  therefore I think about it so as to  not get depressed about being here.
But I'm here, I know I'm here, I  don't like being here, but I can't  be anyplace else because I look around  and I see all this shit. How do you  get around that?! That's what I'm  asking.
Focus.
Focus.
Divinci nods. Rodriguez looks at his watch.
It's time. No more Hawaii, okay?  Focus on this.
(smiles) Aloha.
Rodriguez shakes his head, exasperated, and exits.
(to himself) Aloha my ass.
Poor side of town. A few old cars parked on the street. S buildings vacant. A LATE MODEL WHITE CADILLAC cruises pas We HEAR LOUD RAP MUSIC.

LIONEL HUDD drives. Hudd is thirty. African American. The MUSIC is loud. His clothes lean to African roots. A WOMAN sits next to the passenger window. Her name is CYNTHIA WE Cynthia is thirty-five, dressed in short provocative skir tight top. A little too much make-up. She's lead a hard l She glances at Hudd. Hudd glances at her, looks down at h skirt hiked up on her leg.
Left at the corner.
Hudd's eyes linger on her thighs for a moment, then he tu his attention back to driving, tapping along with the hea bass.

The Cadillac pulls into the parking lot. Parks in front o room SEVEN. Hudd gets out, looks around. Cynthia gets out leads him to SEVEN. Knocks. The curtains pull back. Divinci looks at Hudd and Cynthia She nods to him. The door unlocks and opens. Cynthia enters. Hudd looks around again. Then follows.
Divinci waits at the door. He and Hudd eye each other as  Hudd enters the room. Divinci looks out, making sure no o has followed, then shuts the door.
Hope you don't mind me checkin' you  for weapons.
Hell yes I mind.
Divinci hesitates. This could break the deal.
I just don't want no man handlin'  me.
Hudd looks at Cynthia. The suggestion is taken.
Okay. Check him.
Hudd spreads his legs, lifts his arms. Cynthia would rath not have the job, but there's no choice.
Lotta good hidin' places on this  body. Check good.
Cynthia runs her hands over Hudd, checking pockets, pants sleeves. Finally coming to his crotch. Hudd smiles.
Careful. It's loaded.
Cynthia has heard it all before. She's not squeamish in t least and she gives him a good going over.
He's got nothin'.

She smiles back at Hudd. Then moves away, sits on the cou and seductively crosses her legs. Divinci, satisfied, pulls a PLASTIC BAG packed tight with COCAINE out of his pocket, tosses it to Hudd. Hudd sits on the couch, opens the bag, sticks his finger and tastes the contents. But never takes his eyes off Div
Not bad, not bad. Any more where  this came from?
Maybe.
Then maybe we talk again.
Maybe.
Hudd stands, unzips his pants. Reaches in to grab his coc but instead, pulls out a stack of MONEY. Inch thick.
Told you there was a lotta good hidin'  places on this body.
Hudd hands the money to Divinci and pockets the plastic b Then crosses to the door. Glances back at Cynthia.
Bet you gotta lotta nice hidin'  places, too.
Then Hudd smiles and exits.
Hudd gets into his Cadillac, pulls out of the motel parki lot.
Deserted. No one on the street this late. Several of the  buildings are boarded up.

Hudd drives. No music this time. His attitude has changed More serious. LIGHTS in the REAR VIEW MIRROR. Coming up f Hudd watches as the car pulls around to pass. He glances at the CAR as it pulls past him, but all we SE is the FLASH OF A BLAST FROM A GUN. Front WINDOW EXPLODIN

swerves into a parked car. The OTHER CAR -- a BUICK REGAL screeches to a stop next to it. ONE MAN gets out. Moving  quickly to the Cadillac. It's dark, difficult to see. He  carries a SMITH AND WESSON .44. Opens the door. He's wear PLASTIC GLOVES. Hudd is dead, slumped against the passenger door. The man reaches in, turns off the engine, grabs the plastic bag o cocaine. And now we see it's Divinci.
Rodriguez is the driver. Anxious. Engine running.
Come on! Hurry up!
Divinci dashes back to the Buick, hops in. Rodriguez floo it.
tears off down the dark street.

Not a great part of the city. Apartment buildings line bo sides of the street. An alley runs between two of the  buildings. A TAXI pulls up in front. HEADLIGHTS SHINING o MAN passed out in the street. Cynthia exits the taxi. The taxi pulls away. She glances the man passed out in the street. His clothes are ragged. He's filthy. His face covered in  beard and greasy dirty hair. Hard to tell how old he is.  Maybe forty. Maybe eighty. Who knows? His hand clutches a bottle in a bag.
Hey, Joe, wake up. Get outa the street  before you get run over. Joe, wake  up!
She nudges him with her foot. The man groans, rolls back. Dead drunk.
You're in the street, Joe. Get outa  the street.
The man, JOE, is silent for a moment, then he starts to c toward the middle of the street.
Other way, Joe.
Joe turns his crawl toward the curb. Cynthia watches him a moment. He is truly pathetic.
Forget it, Joe. Maybe you're better  off right there. I don't think you'd  even feel it.
Cynthia enters the building next to the alley.
asleep. The room is dark. We HEAR a door open and close.  Cynthia wakes.
Who is it?
Divinci crosses to the bed.
Got your money.
Put it on the table.
She closes her eyes, trying to go back to sleep.
Tired?
Yes.
I'm not.
Take a sleeping pill. There's some  in my purse.
You want your money?
Cynthia's eyes open and she looks up at Divinci. He's smi holding up FIVE ONE HUNDRED DOLLAR BILLS.
I already worked for that.
Divinci unzips his pants.
This is a bonus.
For who?
Divinci smiles. Cynthia snatches the money. Divinci start to undress.
This ain't my fault. This is a failure  of our educational system. If you  hadn't fallen through the cracks and  dropped outa school, you wouldn't be  here now.
So what's your excuse?
I'm in love.
Cynthia just stares at him for a long beat. Then she unbu Divinci's pants.

A door is pushed open. Rodriguez enters his one bedroom  apartment. Starts to shut the door when TWO MEN appear fr the shadows. The first is short, well dressed. His name i VIC. The second is large, heavy-set, shaved head. His nam is CUTLESS SUPREME. Cutless Supreme is not a man to be me with.
Keepin' some late hours.
Rodriguez looks at Cutless Supreme.
What the hell you doin'? What're my  neighbors gonna think?

I apologize. I understand your  concerns. But you must understand  that, unlike a bank, I cannot rely  on a late fee as sufficient  encouragement to repay one's debts.  I am forced to employ the likes of  Mr. Cutless Supreme, whom I might  add, contributes significantly to my  overhead. I am the real loser here.  And I am concerned about your  sincerity in repaying the twenty- seven thousand, nine hundred forty- two dollar gambling debt that is one  week past due. What can you do to  reassure me of your good intentions?
I can make your life fuckin' miserable  that's what I can do.

Look at me. Do I have a wife and  three kids? Do I have a good job at  IBM? Am I a handsome guy? No, no and  no. I loan money at excessively high  interest rates to pricks like you  who can't control their urges to  lose big money playing cards and  then I am forced to stay up all night  trying to convince them that I have  needs, too. The point of which is, I  already have a fuckin' miserable  life. So don't threaten me you lousy  bag of cat shit.
Rodriguez steps toward Vic, but Cutless Supreme slides in between them. Rodriguez isn't going to win this one.
All I'm askin' is that you be  responsible. Is that unreasonable?
Rodriguez backs off, hesitates as he runs over his option There aren't any. He reaches into his pocket, pulls out s of his night's earnings.
Four thousand is all I got.
I am proportionally reassured. You  purchased yourself an extension.
Vic takes the money, heads for the street. Rodriguez watc Vic walk away. Cutless Supreme watches Rodriguez.
Cutless Supreme, what kind of fuckin'  idiot name is that?
It was the car my daddy stole to  take my momma to the hospital, but  the cops stopped him and shot him  dead in an alley before he could  explain. I was born in the back seat.
Rodriguez glares at Cutless Supreme, then he shuts the do

CRIME SCENE PHOTOGRAPHS -- Dead drug dealers lying where  they were shot. Overlapping CLOSE-UPS of EVIDENCE TAGS an SHELVING filled with EVIDENCE from hundreds of crime scen And CLOSE-SHOTS of CRIME SCENES -- chalk outlines -- bull shells - bloody foot prints. And finally CRIME SCENE TAPE The BLACK AND WHITE fades back into COLOR --

surrounding the CADILLAC. We PULL BACK, revealing COPS  controlling the area. It's early morning. A FEW PEOPLE ha stopped to watch. But this is not a high traffic area. ANOTHER CAR pulls up. Unmarked. Two men get out. We FOLLO BEHIND THEM as they approach the Cadillac and PATROLMAN  MAHONEY, who knows them.
Another day, another body. Where you  wanna start?
A hit?
Looks like. Could be gang related.
And now we SEE THE TWO MEN from the unmarked car. It's DI and RODRIGUEZ. Suit and ties. They act like they own the  area. And they do.
Happened sometime last night, early  morning, two, three o'clock. African- American male, looks like in his  thirties. But even that's a guess.  Half his head is on the upholstery.
Any witnesses?
Oh, sure, hundreds.
The bloody scene is untouched. Hudd's body is where it fe on the seat. Dried blood everywhere. Divinci looks in.
Fuckin' Animals.

EVIDENCE ROOM. Behind a locked fenced in area. A DESK OFF checks in and out all evidence. He is twenty-eight, wears glasses, very clean cut. TWO DETECTIVES are checking in  evidence as Divinci walks in.
...three shotgun shells, twelve gauge.
The Desk Officer checks in the evidence.
Three shotgun shells, twelve gauge.
The two detectives wave hellos to Divinci as he approache
Heard you got a gang related. Lucky  guy, Divinci. You get all the pretty  ones.
One less drug store on the street.
And the world is a safer place.
The Desk Officer buzzes Divinci through the door. Divinci crosses to the --

-- filled with shelves. Stacked with evidence from on-goi investigations. And the shelves are full of guns, knives, bloody gloves, masks, shoes, etc. Divinci looks around, then removes the PACKAGE OF COCAINE and the .44 from his pockets and places them back on one the shelves. CASE NUMBER C-549087. One thing about the .4 which we can see now -- a BLACK STAIN on the metal of the handle.

Desks, phones, computers, typewriters and HOMICIDE DETECT Some witnesses being interviewed. Rodriguez is on the pho at his desk. He's in the middle of an interview as he fil out one of the many forms that complicate his life.
(into phone) -- a green car... you know what  make... Maybe a Ford, uh-huh. You  didn't see the license, did you?
Divinci comes back to his desk, next to Rodriguez. Rodrig looks up. Divinci gives him a confident smile and brushes his hands together -- clean hands.
(into phone) Yeah, no, I understand, it was dark...  Uh-huh.
Divinci sits at his desk. He pulls an ADVERTISEMENT for a FOOT SPORT FISHING BOAT out of his desk. He holds it up t Rodriguez, points to the boat.
Wanna go for a ride?
(into phone) You think you could describe the  driver? (covers phone; to  Divinci) You bought it?
As of last night, I've got the down.  Just picture me under swayin' palms  with a Mai Tai.
We can HEAR someone describing a felon over the phone, bu Rodriguez isn't listening. He's looking at the boat.
(into phone) Uh-huh. (covers phone) You're gonna buy it, no shit. When?
Just a phone call away.
Divinci picks up the phone, starts to dial.
That's really great, man.
Divinci smiles. Rodriguez suddenly realizes the person on the other end of the phone has stopped talking.
(back to phone) Uh-huh, okay... how tall was he?
A heavy set man in his fifties approaches -- CAPTAIN  HENDERSON.
You got primary on the drug related  this morning on 27th.
I'm workin' it up now.
Who's your second? (Divinci points at  Rodriguez) In my office. Both of you.
Why?
Now.

Captain Henderson doesn't wait for a response. He heads f the office -- an inner office of glass and wood. Divinci looks at Rodriguez, who is suddenly a little nerv We can HEAR the PERSON OVER THE PHONE that he's talking t but he's no longer interested and hangs up on them.
What the hell --
Divinci motions "keep calm."
Henderson is hanging up his coat as Divinci and Rodriguez enter. They aren't the only ones in the office. RICHARD S thirty-two, trim, short cut hair, suit, is waiting.
Detectives Divinci and Rodriguez,  this is Richard Simms. He's with the  D.E.A. He wants to ask you some  questions about your case.
What's the occasion?
You get an i.d. on the victim?
We're waitin' for prints.
Divinci pulls out his note pad.
Car was registered to --
-- Anchor Imports. 81 El Dorado.  Black.
If you got all this, what d'you want  from us?
...The man in the car is Lionel Hudd.
(a little incensed) How d'you know that? (to Henderson) What's goin' on here?
Hudd was DEA, undercover.
Rodriguez and Divinci take the news like a sledgehammer. their frozen expressions we HEAR --

He was workin' a case on syndicate  distribution of drugs on the south  side. But every dealer we tagged  kept getting killed. He finally got  a lead on a girl -- Hudd was a friend  of mine... I'm gonna nail the  sonuvabitch who killed him.
A long beat on Rodriguez and Divinci, then --
We'll do everything we can to help.

screeching around a corner and up a drive into a VACANT L The car skids to a stop and Rodriguez gets out of the dri side, slamming the door and storming off. He's out of his mind. Divinci gets out quickly, follows him. Rodriguez is so fi up and scared he can't stop moving.
SHIT, FUCK, SHIT, JESUS CHRIST!
Calm down!
WE'RE DEAD, WE'RE FUCKING DEAD!
SHUT UP!
FUCK, FUCK, FUCK!
Divinci catches Rodriguez, tries to stop him from flailin about.
STOP IT! YOU HEAR ME, RIGHT NOW,  STOP IT!
GOD, GOD, THIS IS REALLY FUCKIN' OUT  OF CONTROL!
Rodriguez tries to push Divinci away, but Divinci holds o They struggle --
LET GO OF ME!
-- pushing, shoving, falling to the dirt. Divinci jumps o top of him, pulling his pistol and shoving it into Rodrig mouth.
Shut up and listen to me!
Rodriguez glares up at Divinci.
They could be watchin' us right now  you asshole. So fuckin' shape up!  You got it?! (nothing from Rodriguez) I want you to nod!

It takes Rodriguez a moment, but he nods. Divinci pulls h gun out of Rodriguez' mouth, gets off him and holsters hi pistol. Rodriguez is scared to death, not of Divinci, of mess they're in. He just lies in the dirt.
Get the fuck up!
Rodriguez starts to get to his feet. Divinci grabs him, y him up. Pushes him to the car.
Get in the car!
They move back to the car. Rodriguez gets back into the  driver's seat. Divinci moves around to the passenger side Gets in, slams the door shut.
They sit silently in the car for a moment in the middle o the vacant lot. Breathing hard. Dirty. After a beat --
There's no fuckin' reason to panic.
Rodriguez turns slowly and looks at Divinci incredulously
No fuckin' reason to panic? Did you  say no fuckin' reason to panic!
Stop being an idiot! We're the cops  on the case. It's our case. We are  going to find the fuckin' killers.
WE'RE THE FUCKIN' KILLERS!
Since when does that matter?!
Rodriguez stares at Divinci for a beat, then we --
Rodriguez and Divinci are sitting on the car, each with a beer and sharing a bottle of whiskey.
All they want is someone to go down  for the crime, right? Do we care who  goes down for the crime? Fuck no. As  long as someone goes down for the  crime. It's a slot that's gotta be  filled.
Rodriguez is calmer, but still something bothers him --
We killed a cop, doesn't that bother  you?

Of course it bothers me. What d'you  want me to do, turn myself in? Well  I'm not. That's the risk we take  everyday, somebody might pop us,  especially undercover like that. So  he got popped. It happens.
Not by other cops!
I patted him down! He wasn't wearin'  a wire, he had no badge, no gun, how  was I supposed to know?!
A moment of silence, then --

Look, I feel just as bad as you do,  but we gotta start thinkin' about us  here. The important thing is we don't  lose control of the case. We can  never lose control of the case.  Whatever evidence there is goes  through us. We lay down the trail.  Make it nice and logical. We're the  teachers and two and two can add up  to five if it's our classroom.
What're you talkin' about, are you  sayin' we stick somebody with this?
Evidence points wherever we want it  to point. Shit, we can provide so  much evidence, even the asshole we  pick will think he fuckin' killed  him.
You got some asshole in mind?
Just don't worry. We'll find a killer.  There's lots of 'em out there.

THREE AFRICAN AMERICAN YOUTHS, all in their twenties, are hanging on a street corner. Talking. Normal street traffi They give a long hard look to an ATTRACTIVE AFRICAN AMERI WOMAN who walks past. A little chatter. The UNMARKED CAR suddenly screeches to the curb. The blac youths scatter quickly as Divinci jumps out and goes afte the tallest of the three. His name is JAMES. Rodriguez gu the car and gives chase on wheels. James darts across traffic. Divinci running hard after hi Rodriguez spins the car in a u-turn. Racing after them.

James darts down the alley. Narrow, dark, lined with tras bins. Divinci turns into the alley, but he isn't going to catch him. James is almost to the end when the car turns into the al skidding to a stop. Rodriguez jumps out, gun leveled at J No where for him to go. He slows down. Rodriguez moves in from his front, Divinci runs up from behind. James is  disgusted.
What the hell'd I do now?
Divinci removes the PACKAGE OF COCAINE and the .44 from t shelf. CASE NUMBER C-549087.
SLIDING across a table to James, who stops it with his ri hand. Divinci and Rodriguez are across from him.
Ain't my gun.
Never is, is it.
That ain't my fuckin' gun.
He shoves the gun back. Divinci stops it with his arm, ca not to touch it.
Got your fuckin' prints on it.
James quickly realizes what they've done. He lunges for t gun, but Divinci picks it up quickly with a pencil throug the trigger guard. James glares at them with murderous in
Where were you Friday night?
Friday night... last Friday night?
Where were you?
Whatever you think I did went down  last Friday night?
Better have a good alibi, James, or  it's good ali bye-bye.
A beat, then James smiles.
I was in jail you assholes. Check it  out. (starts to laugh) All night. What a couple a dickheads!
Rodriguez and Divinci are silent.
KICKED IN on a grungy small apartment. Divinci and Rodrig burst in, guns drawn. Scaring the shit out of an HISPANIC MAN (CORTEZ) and his half-naked GIRLFRIEND as they watch  television.
NOBODY MOVE! HANDS IN THE AIR! NOW!  MOVE IT!
SLIDING across the table back to Rodriguez and Divinci. C sits across from them. Wearing white t-shirt, baggy pants Tattoos on his arms.
Ain't my gun.
(smiles) Got your prints on it.
(stands; angry) You fuck, I ain't never seen that  gun before!
Where were you last Friday night?
Fuck you. I wanna talk to a lawyer!
Just want they wanted to hear. No alibi.
Lawyer's not gonna help you, Cortez.  All the evidence we got points right  to you.
Cortez stares at them for a moment, then --
Did you say last Friday night?
Cortez smiles and pulls up his shirt, revealing a long sc across his stomach.
Intensive Care, you pindejo fuckin'  gutter shits. And Thursday night,  and Saturday, too. I just fucking  got out this morning.

SLAMMING INTO A WALL, hitting hard, falling back to the d garbage covered alley. He's about twenty-seven, thin, blo hair tied in a pony tail. He wears a flannel shirt, jeans boots. He doesn't want to fight. His name is DAVE.
Alright, alright, alright... shit. I  ain't gonna fight you.
He looks up at Divinci and Rodriguez moving toward him.
Dave is behind the desk handling the .44 with no apparent problem.
Ain't my gun.
That's what they all say.
Wish it was. No better gun than Smitty  and Wes .44 mag with serial numbers  filed off. (opens cylinder) Got any bullets?
Divinci walks around, holds out his hand for the gun.
Who did I kill?
Where were you last Friday night?
You mean, what's my alibi right?
Dave spits on the gun, wipes off his prints with his shir
I was breakin' and entering. Jewelry  store on seventh and Front, about  nine o'clock. Not even close to your  jurisdiction. I got the rocks to  prove it.
He drops the gun, clean of prints onto the table.
Sorry I can't help ya. But one to  five is better than ten to life.
Divinci and Rodriguez stare at Dave. They are not happy.
in plastic pages. A BINDER full of criminal portraits. Di is going through one book. Rodriguez searches another.
Montrose LaJolla...
We pulled him in last year for knifing  that dealer on 32nd.
Yeah. Almost killed him, remember?  He'd be good. (calls out to ANOTHER
Anybody seen Montrose LaJolla?
He's dead. His life partner killed  him in a Domestic D about a month  ago.
Rodriguez suddenly slams his book shut.
Shit!
Divinci looks at him. Rodriguez is angry, tense. Divinci  gives him a look telling him this is not the time and pla for a discussion on this topic.
Take it easy.
This isn't gonna work!
Divinci leans toward Rodriguez.
Nobody said it was gonna be easy.  But let's not advertise our despair...  Okay?
The PHONE RINGS. Divinci picks it up.
(into phone) Divinci.
Captain Henderson is sitting behind his desk. Divinci and Rodriguez are in front of him. Rodriguez is trying to hid his nervousness. Divinci is absolutely cool.
This is our case! Not the goddamn  DEA's!
It's been three days.
We're not fuckin' magicians! What  the hell is three days?! This is a  goddamn murder case! It takes a little  bit of goddamn time!

When a Federal Undercover Officer  goes down, it's never a fuckin' murder  case! I don't like the DEA on my ass  any better than you like 'em on yours.  But this is personal for them and  they want answers. Forget your other  cases and get something, anything  that I can give to them. The last  thing I want is the goddamn F.B.I.  on my back, too.
Divinci and Rodriguez are quiet for a beat, then --
We've got a couple leads. We need a  little more time.
I can't hold 'em off much longer.
This is no fuckin' way to run an  investigation.

Let me tell you both something, if  you don't solve this quick, they're  gonna start askin' why? And they'll  be lookin' to blame somebody in this  department. So my advise to you is,  get something fuckin' fast or turn  over what you've got and get outa  the way.
Rodriguez and Divinci are quiet for a moment, then --
How much time we got?
A couple days. The funeral's this  afternoon.
What funeral?
For Agent Hudd. Simms wants you there.
What for? We didn't know him.

How the hell do I know?! It's DEA,  it's their thing. You're the cops on  the case, I suppose they want you to  know what a great guy Hudd was so  you'll work all that harder to find  his killer. Just go. It'll reassure  'em how much you care and keep 'em  off my ass.

MOURNERS gathered around the grave site. WIFE in tears. M in tears. The men trying their best to hold up. Beyond th family, DEA AGENTS. Simms among them. A show of support a solidarity. A REVEREND delivering --

-- and it is too easy to say that he  was a good man in his job because he  gave more than most. And it's too  easy to say that he was a good man  in his community because he gave  more than others. And it's too easy  to say he was a good man at home  with his family because he was always  there when they needed him. Special  Agent Lionel Hudd was not just a  good man, he was an extraordinary  man. And his death shall not be in  vain.
CAMERA FINDS Divinci and Rodriguez at the back. Rodriguez looks nervous. Divinci notices. Their conversation is qui
Don't Humpty Dumpty on me.
What's that mean?
Your cracks are startin' to show.
(covering) Bullshit.
Divinci sees Simms approaching from the side.
Get your balance. Here comes the  King.
Rodriguez glances toward Simms as he walks up. The  conversation is quiet. Not wanting to disturb the ceremon
Glad you came... Anything break?
Divinci glances at Rodriguez.
Nothin' to brag about. But we've got  a couple new leads we're followin'.

...Look, normally we'd be all over  this, but your Captain seems to think  you can do the job. It's your  territory. I guess you know it better  than anybody. And that can be worth  a lot. But you understand... we won't  wait forever.
Divinci is pissed. He doesn't like Simms.
Just outa curiosity... What happened  to his backup? You guys use backup  on undercover don't you?
It was a new lead. Hudd was afraid  backup would blow his cover. He was  supposed to check in ten minutes  after the deal went down. He never  checked in.
We want this one as bad as you do. A  cop's a cop. We're in this together,  right?
Simms stares at Rodriguez and Divinci for a moment, then returns his attention to the ceremony.
That's why I asked you to come here.  Just so you knew that.
Rodriguez and Divinci walk down the street, hot dogs in h returning to their car parked curbside.
He didn't have backup. You believe  that?! Jesus what a dick.
I don't think we should criticize  that particular decision of his.
I don't care what the reasons are,  you don't play Lone Fuckin' Ranger  on a drug buy. You're just askin'  for it. That's all I'm sayin'.
I don't trust those bastards. They're  not waitin' for us. That's bullshit.  They're runnin' their own  investigation. I know it!
Let 'em. The gun, the coke came from  evidence. The car came from impound.  So what's to find?
That's what I'm afraid of. There's  nothing for them to find. We were  too good.
So what're you worried about?
Nobody is that fuckin' good.
Divinci looks at Rodriguez, then smiles.
Except us.

bumping and grinding her way through her performance. We  don't see her face yet. Just her body. G-string and skin  tight tank top. LOUD MUSIC. MEN in the audience appreciat The room is smoky. LIGHTS swirl over the stage. The tank comes off. WHISTLES and CHEERS. And now we see the dancer it's CYNTHIA.
Cynthia moves down the hall in her g-string and high heel She enters the dressing room.
